Male member of the Parliamentary Visitor Services
team: Welcome to the House of Commons Chamber,

2.text:
the place where our elected representatives,
or Members of Parliament, come to discuss

6.text:
Bills or issues that concern themselves or
their constituents, and to question the Government.

11.text:
Now this is the twentieth-century part of
the building, after it was rebuilt, following

15.text:
the destruction of the original Chamber in
the Second World War. Now when the Chamber

19.text:
was rebuilt, Commonwealth countries contributed
to the cost of the materials to rebuild the

23.text:
place. For example, the doors into the Chamber
are from India and Pakistan, the table of

27.text:
the House from Canada, the Bar of the House
from Jamaica, and the Speaker's Chair from

33.text:
Now the Speaker sits, right behind me, in
the middle of the room, and their job is to

37.text:
keep order during debates and to call MPs
to speak. To his or her right-hand side, on

42.text:
those benches that is where Her Majesty's
Government sit and, behind them, the MPs belonging

51.text:
Opposition sits and, beyond them, is where
the other Opposition parties sit, just underneath

57.text:
Further along is a single chair, which is
used by the Serjeant-at-Arms

61.text:
official who is responsible for the security
in the House of Commons. The Despatch Boxes

66.text:
on the table are where the Prime Minister
and the Leader of the Opposition stand, or

70.text:
whichever Minister or Shadow Minister are
speaking at the time. At the end of the table,

75.text:
at the top and the bottom, are the holders
for the Mace.

78.text:
Now the Mace is a symbol of royal authority,
without which the House of Commons cannot

83.text:
sit and debate. The Mace is brought in and
out of the House by the Serjeant-at-Arms in

88.text:
a procession at the beginning and the end
of each day.

91.text:
Now, if you'd like to come and see the proceedings
here in the House of Commons, the Public Gallery

95.text:
is just above us and anyone can turn up and
ask to be admitted.

98.text:
However,
depending on whatís being debated in the

99.text:
Chamber on that particular day, you might
have to wait a while. If you're a UK citizen,

105.text:
you can apply for a ticket through your local
MP. To find out what legislation and other

109.text:
topics are due to be discussed, then you can
go to the Parliament website at www.parliament.uk

113.text:
Now, right at the back, above the Speaker's
Chair, is the Press Gallery, where accredited

120.text:
journalists and reporters from Parliamentís
Official Report sit.

124.text: Now the Official Report is called Hansard, after

126.text:
the 18th-century printer who produced the
House of Commons Journal, and it's a record

131.text:
of what was said inside this Chamber. Now
the report is produced daily and bound into

136.text:
volumes. It can also be read, and searched
for, on the Parliament website, only a few

141.text: hours after proceedings have taken place.

143.text:
Now people say that this Chamber is a lot
smaller in real life than it looks on TV.

148.text:
Well, that's because when it was rebuilt
after 1945, it was deliberately kept to be

152.text:
the same size, so as to preserve that air
of intimacy. In fact, there's room here for

157.text:
about 430 of the 650 Members of Parliament
[Transcriber's note: 650 was the total number

159.text:
of MPs at the time the video was produced],
which means, on particularly busy Parliamentary

163.text:
days, it gets very crowded in here and the
atmosphere is electric.

Services team: The other films in this series

will show you the debating chambers used by
the Lords and Commons, as parts of the old

Palace, as well as introducing you to the
work that Parliament does. We hope you enjoy
